items.title: zombies
items.body:
Sometimes tesseract spawns subprocesses. This causes timeouts which use SIGKILL, to leave the child processes in a zombie state.
I know upstream python uses the same technique but it has also this problem.
This behaviour is especially visible in docker containers (even with init shell).

One way to solve this problem would be a victim process which terminates itself after timeout and killing subprocesses with SIGKILL.

items.title: Pytesseract seems to be ignoring custom configurations
items.body:
Hello, there! 
I am developing a script to measure Tesseract's accuracy for some files. Therefore, I need to run Tesseract on the same page of a pdf with different psm and oem options. Right now I am using the tesseract 4.0.0-beta.1 and pytesseract 0.3.4. The custom config is being sent to Tesseract via the following function:
~~~
pytesseract.image_to_pdf_or_hocr(img, lang='por', extension='hocr', config=config)
~~~
I have triple checked and everything seems to be ok with the config string. This is how I create it:
~~~
config = '--psm ' + PSM[int(id_config)-1] + ' --oem 1'
~~~
The weirdest thing is that even if I set custom configs like that, I get the same hocr result. It's not the proper response, since if I run the same configs directy on Tesseract there are different outcomes.

Aditional info: the exact same script works perfectly on my coworkers' computers (both of them run Windows), meaning that they get the proper (different) results for each config. I am currently trying to run the script on my recently formatted computer (Ubuntu 18.04).

items.title: Speed up pyTesseract
items.body:
Hi, so I'm trying to run pyTesseract on a number of images in python. I've noticed it takes about 500ms to run on one image, but I also noticed that I have to give it the language every time (or use whatever is the default language).

When I make the call `pytesseract.image_to_string(` does it load the language file each time? Is there a way to load the language file once, save my pytesseract instance in RAM (as a variable), and then call a similar `image_to_string` function that doesn't load the language file each time, and instead uses the one I loaded and saved into RAM?

Would this even improve the speed at all for inferencing multiple images?

I saw there's a way to batch process multiple files at once:
`# Batch processing with a single file containing the list of multiple image file paths
print(pytesseract.image_to_string('images.txt'))`

But I may not have all of the images at once, and I'd just like to speed up the pytesseract process, maybe by only loading the language file once?

What other ways are there to increase the speed of pytesseract?

Thanks!

The problem disappear so far.

items.title: 'image_to_data' output type 'DataFrame' : config options needed for "N/A" in input image
items.body:
hello,

We got some problems with image_to_data function. 

When we put some images containing "N/A" text  in pytesseract.image_to_data function with output type 'Data.Frame', pandas automatically converts these "N/A" as nan to create the dataframe. 

The problem is that when we need to remove real nan, we also remove "N/A" text that are important in our output text. To fix it, we have to modify the pytesseract.py file and add in line 386 the option "keep_default_na =False, na_values = ["nan"].

That's a problem because we need to do this every time we install pytesseract in a new environment...

items.title: Update Tesseract for testing
items.body:
Hello,

it would be great if we could add the next stable version of Tesseract for testing. In addition we could update the version of the operating system. I mean, why not 😌?

1. Tesseract (current 3.04.01) to 4.1.0 (ppa [~alex-p/+archive/ubuntu/tesseract-ocr](https://launchpad.net/~alex-p/+archive/ubuntu/tesseract-ocr), required)
2. Ubuntu Ubuntu Xenial 16.04 (current) to Bionic 18.04 (optional)

Reasons:
- Unit tests broke in a PR https://github.com/madmaze/pytesseract/pull/215, b/c of an old version of Tesseract and/or Leptonica
- Feature requests like https://github.com/madmaze/pytesseract/issues/172 (related to https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/issues/785#issuecomment-451682596) require a newer version of Tesseract

Solution:

We could use Travis to test `pytesseract` with Tesseract-OCR 3.04.01 and 4.1.0 on Bionic 18.04 using a simple Dockerfile. I can do that and create a PR, but in this case it would be great to get some opinions first.

Edit:

Fix and change Xenial version from 14.04 to 16.04.

items.title: Unexpected behavior (bug?) while using `pytesseract.image_to_string`
items.body:
I'm cropping an image and then passing it into `pytesseract.image_to_string`

This is `img_original`
![frame667](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17111474/59097660-c1dbe400-893b-11e9-874a-9788b92a1047.jpg)

```python
from PIL import Image
(x1, y1, x2, y2) = (125, 38, 322, 105)
img_scoreboard = img_original.crop(x1, y1, x2, y2)
```

`img_scoreboard`:
![test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17111474/59097995-ac1aee80-893c-11e9-9770-e5b4e5d3098a.jpg)


When I pass the cropped image directly into `pytesseract`, it gives me an incorrect output:
```python
config = ("-l eng --oem 1 --psm 6")
pytesseract.image_to_string(img_scoreboard, config=config)

# Output --> 'MURRAY |0 4\ni2)3,11 a'
```

Whereas if I use either one of the following 3 options, they all give me the correct output:
```python
temp_img = "img_scoreboard.jpg"
pytesseract.image_to_string(temp_img, config=config)
pytesseract.image_to_string("img_scoreboard.jpg", config=config)
pytesseract.image_to_string(Image.open"img_scoreboard.jpg", config=config)

# Outputs:
# 'MURRAY | 0 4\nFEDERER 1 5'
# 'MURRAY | 0 4\nFEDERER 1 5'
# 'MURRAY | 0 4\nFEDERER 1 5'
```

Is this normal?
This means that if you're cropping an image, it needs to be saved to disk and reread while being passed to `pytesseract.image_to_string` ?



Thanks.

items.title: Remove images from being included in the bundled package
items.body:
In [`MANIFEST.in`](https://github.com/madmaze/pytesseract/blob/master/MANIFEST.in#L1-2):

```
recursive-include src *.jpg
recursive-include src *.png
```

These images aren't needed for the actual operation of the package, but are included so they take up extra disk space for users. It seems like if anything, we'd want to move these to a `tests` folder and not include them in the distributed package.

Any reason not to remove these from the package?

items.title: Enable Travis CI for project
Fix README to not claim tesseract-ocr only supports tiff and bmp
items.body:
The README has the claim 

> tesseract-ocr by default only supports tiff and bmp

This is not true since tesseract uses Leptonica, which supports "JPEG, PNG, TIFF, BMP, PNM GIF, and WEBP formats" http://tpgit.github.io/UnOfficialLeptDocs/leptonica/README.html#image-i-o

The later usually yields more text.

Link to [Popen.wait](https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.Popen.wait) notes reference:
=======================

> Note This will deadlock when using stdout=PIPE or stderr=PIPE and the child process generates enough output to a pipe such that it blocks waiting for the OS pipe buffer to accept more data. Use Popen.communicate() when using pipes to avoid that.

> Note The function is implemented using a busy loop (non-blocking call and short sleeps). Use the asyncio module for an asynchronous wait: see asyncio.create_subprocess_exec.

items.title: The purpose of discard and replace the alpha channel
items.body:
During identify speed bottleneck, I found that text result is inconsistent when passing file and Image.Image format. 

If file path is passed, it will pass to tesseract directly. Otherwise, image preparation will be done. Found that text result is better if passing file path rather than image. Text results are same if comment out the following code.

```
if 'A' in image.getbands():
        # discard and replace the alpha channel with white background
        background = Image.new(RGB_MODE, image.size, (255, 255, 255))
        background.paste(image, (0, 0), image)
        image = background
```

Would you mind advising the purpose of this code snippet? 

Thanks.
Edward

items.title: Hangup when passing in long list of images
items.body:
Tesseract has the option of taking in a text file containing a list of images to process. This is a much faster way of processing a series of images instead of having to reinitialize Tesseract for each one. 

This module also correctly handled a text file containing a list of images if the list was short (<50). 

`text = pytesseract.image_to_string(txt_file_of_img_file_names, config=tess_config)`

Longer lists of images lead to the module being hung up indefinitely and it never returned a result. Tesseract has no problem handling this larger txt file from the command line. The problem seems to be with pytesseract.

in pytesseract.py
